Health & Safety for Licensed Child Care Providers, Module C  
Section 3: Emergency Preparedness, Response & Recovery

Protecting the Most Vulnerable

So how do we protect the most vulnerable that are under our care?

Preparing for emergencies is very challenging in a child care situation. Infants, toddlers, and preschoolers do not possess the developmental skills required to care for themselves. They are totally dependent on you. Your plan must be different than that of another facility or a school. You can not tell the children under your care to just leave the building in the face of an emergency. The unique needs of this age group must be considered when writing and implementing your emergency plan. Now we will look at some of those specific needs.


  • Reliance on Caregivers

    Children in child care are physically and emotionally dependent on their providers. They will look to you for how to respond, where to go, what to take, and what to do.

  • Communication & Identification

    The youngest children will not be able to verbally identify themselves. Even older children in your care may not know who their emergency contacts are or how to reach them. Therefore, it is crucial that your emergency kit includes identification cards for children and emergency contact information.

  • Mobility

    Infants are unable to walk. Toddlers may need to hold hands for balance and move at a slow pace. Your emergency plan must include ways to safely evacuate every child and the necessary evacuation equipment, such as car seats, cribs, and transportation.

  • Safety & Protection

    In the middle of an emergency it is important to have enough adults to care for the children and supplies to meet their needs. Caution must also be taken that small children do not have access to some of the dangerous supplies in the emergency kit or in the building you have evacuated to.

  • Physical Needs

    Children’s bodies are more physiologically vulnerable. Their bodies are smaller and less developed than adults’. This puts them at greater risk for illness or harm during an emergency. Children have thinner skin, take more breaths per minute, and are closer to the ground. This makes them more susceptible to harmful chemicals and carbon monoxide poisoning. They also have more daily person-to-person contact which makes them more susceptible to contagious threats.

  • Nutritional Needs

    Children have unique nutritional needs. They require more fluids pound for pound then adults. Ample fluids must be kept in the emergency kit and insurance of hydration written into the plan. Remember that some children can be picky eaters so include child-friendly healthy snacks in the kit. Remember to include formula for infants, ensuring it has not expired when the kit is checked.

  • Emotional Needs

    Children are deeply affected by disasters. These reactions are affected by caregivers' reactions and separation from parents. Children process these events with limited understanding and require specialized support. This will be discussed in more detail further in this section.

  • Routine & Comfort

    As much as possible maintain routines in the middle of the crisis. Routine helps comfort children. Children are also comforted by certain toys, blankets, and stuffed animals. Be sure these items are included in the emergency kit.
